title: Thursday, 20th October, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

Even tho I'm still feeling half-dead

PM

PM

PM

PM

Poor service, typical of brexit Britain Shall I also suspend my FT subscription when I'm ill or don't feel like reading it? This isn't very professional IMO.

omg smile

PM

PM

undefined

11:06 am

I think, cos obviously I'm out of the loop

PM

Having been ill

PM

But we'll struggle on

11:07 am
PM

Footsie off a couple of points currently

PM

trading around 7020

PM

Don't you think it's weird how, in the modern age, equities don't really respond to changes in political risk?

11:08 am
PM

Trump's finished, right?

PM

There will be no wall

PM

America will not cut itself off from the world.

11:08 am
PM

Putin will not be allowed to takeover Estonia or whatever

PM

Conversely, there probably will be action on US drug prices

PM

And there may be action against Wall St

11:09 am
PM

But does it show through in equity prices? No

PM

I was speaking to Tina Fordham, Citi's terrific political analyst, the week before last.

PM

I asked her the same question.

11:10 am
PM

And she just said: "It's cos of QE" and shrugged her shoulders

PM

chad_john -- you are right.

PM

I will leave the subject alone.

11:11 am
undefined

Having run that Sky vid above, I notice Sky have an investor day today

PM

At Osterley

11:12 am
PM

What a place to be based.

PM

I went for lunch there once, back in the day, with Tony Ball

PM

They sent a car to pick me up -- cos that's what broadcasters do

11:13 am
PM

And it took four hours to get there

PM

Anyway,

PM

Within the presentations, Sky will give details on a wide range of topics including its strategy, capabilities, position in each market, content strategy, cost efficiency and its advertising business. In addition, Sky will today give an update on its progress towards the launch of Sky Mobile and will announce that customers can register their interest in the service from 31st October.

11:14 am
Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 834.50, down 21.5 (-2.51%), High: 857.00, Low: 834.50, Volume: 2.83m
PM

(We're looking at Trump TV in the US and on Facebook -- but I won't go there)

I missed the Pearson fun, of course

11:20 am
PM

Bounced yesterday, but weakening again this morning

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 756.00, down 5 (-0.66%), High: 761.00, Low: 750.50, Volume: 689.76k
PM

A tad

11:21 am
PM

Liberum been determined sellers here

PM

But the short advice hasn't quite delivered

PM

Yet

11:01 am
PM

Welcome back to Markets Live

PM

And also, it's a big dollar earner

PM

Northern Trust also bears on this

11:23 am
PM

Here's a couple of pars from Neil Campling earlier in the week

PM

three pars actually

PM

Pearson trading update. If current exchange rates persist until the end of 2016 EPS guidance range will increase by approximately 4.5p to 54.5-59.5p, c.8%. Sales were down -3% for the first nine months of 2016 in headline terms but declined -10% in CER (constant exchange rates).

11:23 am
PM

Sales were affected by retailer inventory correction in July/August with trends improving in September and October. Pearson highlight that trends improved in September/October for seasonal reasons (back to school) but it remains to be seen if the improvements can continue in the face of significant industry challenges. The most alarming trend is that the key North American market is alarmingly weak with sales falling -13% in CER terms. While guidance has been reiterated, the 3Q organic growth was -7% at the group level and -9% in N America, continuing the weak trend of 1H16 and slightly worse than consensus expectations for -5% organic growth. On an underlying basis, FY16 guidance has been reiterated with lower sales offset by the restructuring efforts to reduce costs.

PM

Pearson’s stated growth and simplification plan requires a stable K-12 core business and stable HE enrolments to meet their target. Other headwind risks include U.S. State renewal RFPs, US politics, EM slowdown and the rising threats of new MOOCs (Massive Open Online Courses) and new OER (Open Educational Resource) platforms. Sterling has fallen by c.18% since the Brexit vote and these EPS upgrades are just 8% (U.K. is c.10% of revenues). While cost cutting measures have so far delivered to the “simplification plan” the other part of the “growth and simplification plan”, the rather important “growth” plan is nowhere in sight in our view. We see that there is a risk that the tight cost controls could end up exacerbating the (lack of) growth risk. We remain sellers of Pearson.

PM

Cost-cutting does seem to be the only thing Mr Fallon knows how to do.

11:25 am
PM

You know in the year before the FT was sold to Nikkei, Fallon simply halved all the bonuses due to the executive management here

PM

Reason? No reason.

PM

The division hit all targets and was the best performing division across Pearson, so he halved all the top brass bonuses.

11:26 am
undefined
PM

(VIXAL -- Gavin has just escaped the markets desk. He's joining the economics team, which means he has to sit upstairs in a grand office overlooking the Thames and suck his pen all day.)

PM

So one sector I've never really got my head round is challenger banks

11:30 am
PM

There are funny challenger banks, like Metro.

PM

Metro trading close to £27. Why? Dunno

PM

And then things like Virgin Money

11:31 am
PM

Trader Gordon's talking about them this morning

PM

ON the back of mortgage lending date

PM

Gross lending up 11 per cent quarter on quarter

11:32 am
PM

Ian Gordon of Investec of course

PM

He's a frustrated buyer

PM

Frustrated in the sense that his number's a rather different from his competitors

11:33 am
PM

Let me let him explain

PM

Whereas we certainly think Virgin Money is far too cheap, we do not regard it as having the biggest valuation anomaly in the sub-sector – see Aldermore (Buy), OneSavings (Buy) and Shawbrook (Buy) for that. However, we struggle to think of any example in history where consensus volume assumptions for any stock have been so manifestly wrong. We think today’s CML mortgage lending data – which shows Q3 2016 gross lending of £63.6bn, up 11% QoQ – makes this more a statement of fact rather than opinion. BUY.

PM

Gross mortgage lending in September 2016 of £20.5bn (up 2% YoY) makes £63.6bn for the quarter, so Q3 2016 has been the best quarter for 33 quarters (i.e. since Q2 2008), see Figure 1, page 2 for detail. So much for the post “Independence Day” slowdown almost universally predicted by the sellside!

11:33 am
PM

But even in the face of such compelling data, the sellside appears unwilling to move its volume forecasts for Virgin. As a reminder (see Figure 2, page 2 for detail), Virgin Money achieved record gross mortgage lending of £2.1bn in Q1 2016, rising to a new record £2.2bn in Q2 2016. In both quarters, this translated into (record) net lending of £1.1bn.

PM

For Q3/Q4 2016e (and beyond), consensus currently models a sharp (c.40% QoQ) fall in net lending to c.£0.65bn per quarter. Is such an outcome even possible in Q3 2016? It would, we suggest, require either (1) a collapse in Virgin’s market share of gross mortgage lending from c.3.6% in H1 2016 to c.2.0% in Q3 2016e, (it targets 3-3.5%); or (2) a sharp deterioration in retentions experience, in contrast to Virgin’s notably improved performance in H1 2016.

PM

We concede that the 2017 mortgage market outlook remains a matter for legitimate debate, although with c.60% of Virgin’s flow driven by remortgage activity, we expect its volumes to prove far more resilient than for its larger peers. As regards 2017, we strongly suspect that consensus fails to give due credit for the material NIM support the Term Funding Scheme may offer, and we think its impairment assumption of 30bps (vs 12bps in H1 2016) is ludicrous.

11:34 am
PM

We are 5%, 24% and 28% ahead of Bloomberg EPS consensus through H2 2016-2018e. Buy rec reaffirmed. TP raised to 385p (from 375p).

PM

It is of course true that none of the immediate post Brexit predictions of doom have played out.

PM

But I still have this fear that we've witnessed Peak London

11:35 am
PM

Youngsters can't afford to live here

PM

All the new towers are empty -- the flats owned by the Chinese

PM

Roads are gridlocked cos of the stupid cycle superhighway

11:36 am
PM

But we'll see

undefined
PM

Bear with me a mo

11:38 am
PM

This is alarming -- for those of us partially reliant on gross watch sales

PM

Swiss watch exports were down 6% in September. This follows the negative trend seen in Aug at -9% and Jul at -14%
bringing the YTD decline to 10%. Admittedly, the comps were easier than in previous months but there was no extra
working day. HK recorded its 20th month of double-digit decline with exports down 40% in Sep, China was broadly flattish
after being up +29% in Aug. Europe's largest export countries saw double-digit declines bar the UK, which continues to
benefit post the EU referendum.

PM

This is from a Credit Suisse note

11:39 am
PM

Inventory swaps may have boosted exports numbers. As we discussed in yesterday's report (see Trying to make sense of
the recent share price moves), the exports may have benefited from the inventory swaps of the last few months. The
buyback of stocks is indeed not deducted from the exports numbers while the more affordable watches that are ordered in
exchange are accounted for. In fact, we note that exports of steel watches were up +1% in Sep following +6% in Aug.

PM

We believe destocking is likely to continue. Our updated analysis of the inventory backlog currently in the wholesale
channel implies we are only halfway through the destocking cycle (see Time to buy it? Sadly not). The c.40 respondents in
the latest KOF survey (see Introducing the KOF survey) anticipate further production cuts on the back of weak incoming
orders. Finally, our channel checks suggest that that sell-out is seeing some encouraging signs in HK with LFL trends
becoming less negative in 3Q relative to 1H for the three listed watch retailers. However, we believe this is mostly down to
easy comps and a transfer of demand out Japan. Given that the watch businesses of Richemont and Swatch Group are
predominantly wholesale, we rate both stocks Underperform.

PM

Richemont trading unchanged at around 66 euros, for what it's worth

11:41 am
PM

Touched a low of 53 aroudn the time of the Brexit vote
